At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse again, saying:
External things, though adorned, all return to destruction; the decaying of the body is also the same.
Only the supreme Dharma is not destroyed; the wise ones should observe well.
Old age, sickness, and death are all despised; the appearance is ugly and extremely detestable.
The youthful appearance only lingers for a while; before long, it all becomes withered and haggard.
Even if one's lifespan is a full hundred years, in the end, one cannot escape the oppression of impermanence.
Old age, sickness, and death always follow, constantly causing harm to sentient beings.
At that time, the World-Honored One, having finished expounding this sutra,

Suffering and death come together - at that time, one merely laments in vain, with both eyes rolling up.
The sword of death follows karma, the mind is confused and agitated, there is no one who can rescue and deliver.
Long gasps, with the chest constricted, the throat is dry with choked breath. The king of death urges and watches over life.
Relatives merely watch over each other, all the consciousnesses are dim and confused. One enters the dangerous city of the bardo.
All close ones abandon and discard, leaving one to be dragged away by the black ropes, leading one to the king of Yama.
According to one's karma, one receives retribution. By superior causes, one is born in good destinies. By evil karma, one falls into the hells.
The eyes are not as discerning as wisdom. Darkness is not as great as delusion. Illness is not greater than enmity.
There is no greater terror than death. Those who are born will all die. Creating offenses, one suffers in one's body.
One should diligently strive in the three karmas and always cultivate merit and wisdom. Relatives all abandon one.
Wealth and goods are taken by others. Only one's own wholesome roots can be taken along. They are like provisions on a dangerous road.
It is like a tree by the roadside. One rests for a while, but does not stay long. Cars, horses, wives and children
will not last long like this. It is like a flock of roosting birds. At night they gather, and in the morning they fly away.
When one dies, one is separated from one's relatives and acquaintances. Separation is also like this. Only the Buddha's enlightenment
is the true place of refuge. Relying on the sutra, I have briefly explained. The wise should carefully consider.
Devas, asuras, yakshas and others who come to listen to the Dharma should be sincere in mind.
